pr_title: DB-11067/DB-11111 SpliceCatalogUpgradeScripts UpgradeScriptForTablePriorities fix, cleanup, tests

timeline.message: DB-11067 SpliceCatalogUpgradeScripts can run multiple scripts for one version

timeline.bodyText: Nitpick, you can use Long.compare(v1, v2);
timeline.author: dgomezferro

timeline.bodyText: Move this one to the current version so that it gets executed with the new fixed logic. I think it already handles tables that have the expected priority, right?
timeline.author: dgomezferro

timeline.message: DB-11067 SpliceCatalogUpgradeScripts can run multiple scripts for one version
DB-11067 add tests for parts of SpliceCatalogUpgradeScripts

timeline.author: dgomezferro

timeline.bodyText: It'd be great to have more descriptive test names
timeline.author: dgomezferro

timeline.bodyText: Instead of using a List and perform a linear search each time we want to perform an upgrade, I would keep the tree structure used before and replace it with something like Guava's MultiMap instead. To start iterating from version X you can lookup the key in log(N) : N #versions by doing multimap.keySet().ceiling(X)
timeline.author: hatyo

replies.bodyText:
i made this especially easy since the whole upgrade path is really hard to test, people modify it, and if it's broken it's a high cost, while optimal performance is lower priority here. last version was using a sophisticated map, then someone changed it to still iterate over all elements.
this upgrade is called ONCE when database is started, the number of items in the list is currently 22. Even for 100 items i would doubt that creating a multimap + searching is faster than just looping over a list. even if - I would really like to keep this rock-solid-bullet-proof code, and not trying to squeeze out a second or two.
replies.author: martinrupp

replies.bodyText: I agree with @martinrupp , I think it's ok to have a list here since this code is not performance sensitive (at least for now)
replies.author: dgomezferro

replies.bodyText:
I would really like to keep this rock-solid-bullet-proof code, and not trying to squeeze out a second or two.

I think these are not mutually exclusive.
Anyway, it is a fair point that the number of items is too small that the overhead is negligible.
replies.author: hatyo

replies.bodyText:
I would really like to keep this rock-solid-bullet-proof code, and not trying to squeeze out a second or two.



I think these are not mutually exclusive

yes, i agree.
replies.author: martinrupp
